intro: Ocimum polystachyon, commonly known as wild basil, is a herbaceous plant native to tropical regions of Africa and Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, ovate leaves with a fragrant scent. Its small, tubular flowers are usually blue or purple, arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the branches. Ocimum polystachyon is often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb due to its essential oils and medicinal properties.
